security: This document contains intelligence related to Cuban government communications and interpretations of the JFK assassination. Releasing information about the interception and dissemination of these messages could expose NSA's SIGINT capabilities and compromise sources and methods. The document is marked as containing 'sensitive compartmented information'.
summary: This NSA report summarizes Fidel Castro's statements regarding the JFK assassination, where he insinuates a plot by U.S. reactionaries to blame Cuba, and also briefly mentions Cuba's economic projections.
summary_one_paragraph: Dated November 28, 1963, this NSA report, designated 2X/0/CUD/T2456-63, relays Fidel Castro's perspective on President Kennedy's assassination to the Cuban Embassy in Accra and other diplomatic missions. Castro suggests that Lee Harvey Oswald was manipulated to implicate Cuba and the USSR in the assassination, part of a sinister plot by U.S. reactionaries. The message also touches on Cuba's economic progress, projecting sugar production increases by 1970 and improvements in foreign trade, including the reappearance of certain consumer goods.
title: Castro Speaks on President Kennedy's Assassination & Cuba
conspiracy: Castro suggests that Oswald was set up to make it appear that Cuba was involved in the assassination. He argues that Oswald's trip to Mexico to request a transit visa to Cuba before traveling to the USSR was illogical and intended to cast suspicion on Cuba.
